Package de.unkrig.lfr.core

Class CharacterClass

java.lang.Object
de.unkrig.lfr.core.CharacterClass
public abstract class CharacterClass extends Object
A CompositeSequence that implements matches(MatcherImpl) by applying matches(int) onto itself.

    • matches

      public boolean matches(de.unkrig.lfr.core.MatcherImpl matcher)

    • find

      public int find(de.unkrig.lfr.core.MatcherImpl matcher)
      Searches for the next match, starting at the current MatcherImpl.offset, and, iff it finds one, updates MatcherImpl.offset to point behind the match, and returns the index of the start of the match.

      Derived classes may override this method if there is a faster implementation.

      Returns:
      -1 iff there is no match

    • matches

      public abstract boolean matches(int codePoint)
      Returns:
      Whether the codePoint matches this character class

    • lowerBound

      public int lowerBound()
      matches(int) is guaranteed to return false for all subjects smaller than lowerBound().

    • upperBound

      public int upperBound()
      matches(int) is guaranteed to return false for all subjects greater than or equal to upperBound().

    • sizeBound

      public int sizeBound()
      Returns:
      The number of values for which matches(int) returns true, or more

    • checkWithoutNext

      protected void checkWithoutNext(int offset, de.unkrig.commons.lang.protocol.Consumer<Integer> result)
      Same as check(int, Consumer), but ignores the next sequence.
      Parameters:
      offset - 0 ... (maxMatchLengthWithoutNext - 1)

    • concat

      public de.unkrig.lfr.core.Sequence concat(de.unkrig.lfr.core.Sequence that)

    • toStringWithoutNext

      protected abstract String toStringWithoutNext()
      Returns:
      A human-readable form of this sequence, but without the next sequence

    • toString

      public String toString()
      Returns an unambiguous string form of this sequence; practical for verifying a compiled sequence e.g. for correctness, efficiency, etc. The syntax resembles Java.
